So, I do recommend this game, because it's wicked fun, especially with two players, but it does have some problems.

I got this game because I'm really into Batman, and I wanted to try to get my 7 year old daughter into it too.  I was playing Batman: Arkham City with her, but my wife found out about it, and she was not happy.  So, we agreed that this way more kid-friendly game was probably a good compromise.  And it is pretty kid-friendly as far as content goes.  The characters are fun, and building LEGO stuff in-game to make vehicles and such is a blast.  As far as my goal of getting my daughter into Batman, it worked like a charm, and now we're watching the movies and TV shows, and as soon as she can read I will start getting her some of the old comics.  So there's that.

Now the problems:  controls and bugs.  The controls are pretty decent in single-player mode, but all hell breaks loose in multiplayer mode.  Inside a level, if you and your partner are together in the same location, and one of you moves even a tiny bit while the other is doing something where you have to stay in one spot (i.e. aiming a batarang or Superman's heat vision, spraying something with water, etc.) the aim gets totally thrown off.  If your partner is say, just hypothetically, a willful 7-year-old girl who will not listen to repeated cries of STOP MOVING

reviewText:
The Good:
* Great, campy, 70's characters, story and visuals
* Lots to do and collect
* Storymode: good Lego fun around 8 hours
* Replay value with Freeplay clocking in around 16 hours

The Bad:
* Messy hub map interface is confusing for a long time
* Flying (esp with co-op keyboard) is almost impossible to control
* Crashes every few hours
* Small roster of characters with samey powers
* Batarangs have very limited range and weapons fire slowly
* Short 8 hour campaign is all over too soon
* Freeroam has only 5 kinds of task repeated dozens of times
* Co-op mared by bad design (paralysed on: change character, pick vehicle, open map, fight character, start mission, gold brick) really slow save every time you complete a task while baddies beat you up.

Background: Just finished Lego LOTR & Marvel. Like Batman comic books. Indifferent to the 80's-90's movies. Disliked Lego Batman 1.

Impressions: TT's continual changing of the hub world interface really bugs me. From game to game I have no idea how to navigate and spend ages trying to find a story mission.

After playing Lego LOTR and Marvel this feels like a huge let down. Which is unfair since this is a smaller and older game but it makes you appreciate how much better the games got after this.

Recommended for: TT Lego fans and those who like Batman really.

Conclusion: 6/10. You can bump this score up 1 if your not a Gloomy Gus like me.


**SPOILERS AND HINTS**
I wrote this to help newbies understand how to play the game better and not flail around like I did. Follow these tips in the order shown and you'll get more out and less frustration.

The spoilers are very mild (are they even spoilers?) but I'm aware not everyone wants hand holding and they are around mechanics of play, there's nothing about the story or exactly how anything is done.

How to Play:
1. Complete story mode first
* You need to unlock characters in the final mission, don't even start on freeroam or freeplay till you complete

2. Find Characters with unique talents
* In freeroam (use batcomputer, pick a white dot and select to be teleported into town) fly around the sky and head for red skylight beams and land
* Use the computer terminal to find a baddie, note where they are standing as they taunt you (ground, top of building, etc)
* Use the ! MARKER tool to drop a marker on the baddies face in the MAP. Head for the red ! in your batcompass, locate the bad guy and walk up to them
* Most baddies just take a few punches while other require you to do some cleanup or damage to the local environment before take down
* Only buy the ones you want as money can be short at first: Lex, Ivy, Aquaman, Joker & Riddler are the only ones you really need

3. Red Helper Bricks
* To help even more get some red bricks for the now familiar helpers (esp. indicate gold bricks, attract studs, indicate mini-kit parts, stud multipliers)
* Use the batcomputer or the terminals around town (blue skylights easily found with a flying character) and press SCAN on the MAP to find Red dots
* As before use the marker system to mark the red dot, go to it and complete a task to reveal the brick for purchase

4. Freeplay re-runs of the story missions
Now you can better complete freeplay re-runs of the story missions with all the tools you need.
* Use the Batcomputer and select the numbered disks to play the story missions
* Ideally collect all the minikits, rescue the guy in peril and get 100% on the stud collector for extra gold bricks

5. Get Cash for freeroam vehicles, characters and red bricks
* To get cash I found the stud multipliers, turned on, switch to Green Lantern, build and smash the green piles around the streets in the middle map for purple and blue studs

6. How to use the Map system.
While Scanning you also reveal dots that lead you to the following...
* Citizens in Peril: Save the poor soles from their situation for a gold bricks
* Collapsed arches: rebuild, if you have enough gold bricks, to reveal a bonus character to buy
* Beat up baddies: beat enough and you can add them to your roster
* Stud trails: leading to gold bricks which require certain outfits and characters
* Gold items: Melt with heat vision to reveal gold bricks
* Riddler/Joker boxes: Only they can open these and usually have a red brick in them
* Flash Builds: Only Flash can build these structures
* Vehicles: Shown on the map and take serious cash to buy
* Environmental tasks: shooting stuff, remote-control, riding and pulling switches
* Water: Aquaman can swim underwater
In Missions...
* Black bricks: Only Lex's ray can shatter them
* Ivy flowers: Able to tunnel through the ground

reviewText:
LEGO Batman 2 is awesome.

Let me break it down; Lex Luthor loses Man of the Year to Bruce Wayne, madness ensues when the Joker breaks the ceremony, cue Bruce Wayne leaving and reappearing as Batman. He saves the day. But, an angry Lex has a new weapon used to let the villains of Gotham loose from Arkham Asylum, the Joker wreaking the most havok. Batman manages to re-capture most of the villains, but the Joker is still on the loose. The rest of the game is an epic story of cat vs. mouse searching and fighting in classic LEGO fashion. Destroying stuff and collecting studs. Unlocking characters and wreaking havok.

What's noteworthy about LEGO Batman 2 is the full voice cast, the open world Gotham, which, while not huge, is respectably big if you're running around as Batman instead of flying across the map as Superman. The graphics are impressive, it seems TT keeps outdoing themselves with the lighting and textures on a number of the models. Gameplay is classic LEGO gameplay. Jump, punch, switch character, special move and camera/movement.

I have to say, especially with how the game ends, I'm very excited for LEGO Batman 3, which will be set in space featuring a different villain, Green Lantern's foe Brainiac.

9.3/10

reviewText:
LEGO, Batman, computer games...you would think combining them would create something wonderful. Sadly, not with 'LEGO Batman' and 'LEGO Batman 2'. I played 'LEGO Batman' and didn't really like it, thinking it was rather dull, frustrating, and hard to control with the keyboard. I later went on to 'LEGO Batman 2', hoping and half expecting improvements.

'LEGO Batman 2' is a whimsical and charming game, and improved upon its predecessor by having actual voice acting in the game. (The first game just featured characters making sound effects, like grunting.) However, this game still has the clunky keyboard controls (the default configuration makes no sense to me), unfriendly camera angles, and wonky pathfinding from the first.

In the end, 'LEGO Batman 2' is a mediocre PC port of a console game at best. TT Games did not bother to optimize it for the PC. The game does not automatically start in your system's default graphic resolution on the first run, which is unacceptable for a modern PC game. Plus, 'LEGO Batman 2' is best played using a controller because its keyboard controls are unintuitive. Reconfiguring the default keyboard controls improved my gaming experience a bit, but I still had to fight the weird game camera positioning.

Furthermore, 'LEGO Batman 2' is really designed for co-op play because the character that I was not controlling was not helpful in fighting off bad guys and solving puzzles in the single-player mode. Yet, the game does not offer online multiplayer. Having two people playing side-by-side may be nice (and nostalgic) if it is done on a console, but less ideal on a PC, especially if both players have to huddle around a single keyboard. That may be acceptable or tolerable back in the early 90s, but not in the 2000s.

Both 'LEGO Batman' and 'LEGO Batman 2' capitalize on our love of LEGO and Batman. It is unfortunate that TT Games did not put a bit more effort into making 'LEGO Batman 2' more PC-friendly, let alone improving on its gameplay. It is frustrating and disappointing to see TT Games seemingly coast in what they do despite having the lucrative properties of LEGO and DC characters to work off of.

reviewText:
LEGO Batman 2 is the first LEGO game that I‚Äôve actually finished. Well, I may be slightly abusing the term ‚Äúfinished‚Äù here. My playthrough ended recently at 22.3%. So ‚Äúabandoned‚Äù might be a more apt characterization, although in fairness to me, I did complete the story mode. I started playing the first game in this series and abandoned it fairly early on, probably due to the fact that the keyboard-and-mouse controls are abominable. Setting up a controller to play and actually playing with a controller are a breeze but do not‚Äìunder any circumstances‚Äìattempt to play this game without one.

All of the LEGO games are built on a similar foundation: smashing enemies and collecting bricks/studs with which to purchase unlocks/abilities. There is some platforming involved but puzzles are essentially limited to figuring out which superpower/suit is needed to remove an obstacle to progress. As such the gameplay is amusing in short bursts but tiresome over the long haul, especially if you‚Äôre 1) over the age of 10; and 2) playing by yourself.

The story is a slight but entertaining tale that begins with The Joker and various other Bat-villains robbing the guests at Gotham‚Äôs Man of the Year awards ceremony and segues into Lex Luthor recruiting The Joker to aid him in his bid to win the presidency of the United States. Batman and Robin eventually have to call Superman to help out, and eventually, with the Last Son of Krypton greatly weakened by exposure to Kryptonite, the JLA shows up to aid in the capture of the evil duo. (Interestingly, Superman is almost too powerful in this game, as he‚Äôs essentially invulnerable to harm and has abilities that the Dynamic Duo need four different suits to replicate.) The game doesn‚Äôt take itself too seriously and once you get past the major conceit that all of these characters are essentially self-aware toys, it‚Äôs pretty funny.

Once you‚Äôve completed the story in LEGO Batman 2, you can take any currently-unlocked character and faff about in Gotham City, looking for imperiled citizens to rescue or miscreants to defeat. Although the game drops frequent hints about nearly every other aspect of gameplay, the method of actually unlocking characters remains somewhat obscure. Occasionally during a fight (for characters) or while wandering the cityscape and passing near an object (for vehicles), you will receive a button prompt and a message advising you that you can purchase that item for x number of studs. Once you do, that item is added to your roster/garage. In the course of your travels, you will discover items that can only be interacted with using the abilities of specific characters such as Poison Ivy, Man-Bat, or The Joker. However, actually obtaining those characters appears to be a surprisingly trial-and-error affair. Upon completion of the story, I had Batman, Robin, Superman, Wonder Woman, The Flash, Green Lantern, Cyborg, and a few assorted goons unlocked for a grand total of 12 out of 60 unlockable characters. (You can also replay any section of the story in ‚ÄúFree Play‚Äù mode (meaning with access to any unlocked character), but of course this approach suffers from the same shortcomings I mentioned above.)

The game looks and sounds great, but we come back to the fundamental problem of gameplay and the nature of LEGO games. These are games that are meant for kids and co-op. They are meant to be played several times, uncovering more bits and bobs on each playthrough. These are all concepts that are antithetical to the way that I play games. I don‚Äôt have kids or a gamer spouse and I rarely play through a game more than once. Kids don‚Äôt really mind repetition and doing the same thing ad nauseum; in fact, I‚Äôd venture to say psychologists probably have some term for a childhood phase during which they absolutely thrive on it. As an adult, I don‚Äôt normally bother with replays simply because if a game offers nothing new on a replay other than a different character, it doesn‚Äôt have enough novel content to justify spending my time.

As a follow-up to the first LEGO Batman title, LEGO Batman 2 has a lot going for it, including a much larger cast of characters, varied levels and a concise storyline, but I think it stands out most for the open-world of Gotham you can explore and (chronologically) the first inclusion of voice-acting to the series. In comparison to its prequel, a number of improvements made the experience much more seamless, including better controls, split-screen multiplayer no longer restricted to a small portion of the level, and puzzles that made better use of additional characters. The vehicle levels, while repetitive, were much more fun to play this time around. I did find some of the Gold Brick puzzles in the open-world somewhat frustrating, whether by poor design or requiring a specific character (and often specific suit). Overall a solid game, the one downside being I felt the new character roster wasn't appropriately integrated, only requiring Superman or Green Lantern a handful of times, and newcomers Flash and Cyborg serving almost no purpose.

LEGO Batman 2 is the sequel to LEGO Batman... which is obvious. I don't completely know why I got this since I didn't care much for the first LEGO Batman, but this one is an improvement. I'm not too far into the game, but I can tell you it is definitely not bad.

The story isn't too bad. The Joker is trying to defeat Batman once again, but this time Lex Luthor is by his side along with many other villains. Like LEGO Marvel Super Heroes, this game mixes the super hero/comic book storyline with what you expect from a Lego game very well.

The gameplay is pretty much what you expect from a Lego game- do missions, build stuff, get gold bricks, get characters, etc. It is fun, but there's something about the LEGO Batman games that seem a bit boring to me as far as levels go and I don't really know what it is. When you aren't doing missions, you can free roam around Gotham City, like you can free roam around New York in LEGO Marvel Super Heroes, and this is pretty fun.

The graphics for LEGO Batman 2 are about the same as most Lego games. Gotham City has the kind of look that reminds you of the Batman Arkham games, which fits very well with Batman. The animations look good as well.

Probably the main problems I have with this game are what I mentioned before about the levels and the amount of characters. I don't have all of them yet, but there don't seem to be very many. From what I can tell, there's probably around 50 of them. Not bad, but still much less than I expected.

LEGO Batman 2 definitely isn't the best Lego game so far, but it is definitely not the worst either. It has a plot that goes good with both Batman/DC Comics and Lego, entertaining free roam, and a good amount of characters. However, if you're looking for a Lego game that you'll be playig for hours at a time, go with LEGO Marvel Super Heroes or LEGO Star Wars.

Better graphics and a great story, really funny as well. The first time you get to fly Superman around the open world Gotham with the classic theme playing in the background? It will be one of your more memorable gaming moments, a slight shame then that the flying controls are so unresponsive and that the open world just amounts to getting to the end of the game and then working down the map, using the correct character or suit on some really easy to follow obstacle courses and vehicles races.

The replay value of the missions is much better, and the red bricks from the earlier games but oddly absent from LEGO Batman 1 are back, allowing the gold bricks just to become progress monitors and a way of limiting which characters you can purchase from certain doorways in the city.

Definitely fun, and the voices add a lot, and there is a genuine sense of humour that fits right in with the characters (Batman dislikes Superman, who is oblivious, but Robin absolutely hero worships him, much to Batman's annoyance). The final missions, when you get to play all the Justice League characters (especially The Flash - the animation for him is just superb on every level) is just a little slice of geek heaven. Definitely fun, and definitely worth getting.

If you've played other IP-based LEGO games by Traveler's Tales, you already know what you're in for.  If not, you don't know  what you're missing!

As usual, this game improves on the system a bit.  The character's powers are quite a bit more varied than usual.  Some characters actually have multiple powers, instead of the usual one-power-per-character.  They also used the power-by-costume system for Batman and Robin, which I'm not really a fan of, but it does add some puzzles to the game.

There is also an open world for the maps between the levels.  Think of GTA, but smaller.

My only complaint is that there are no achievements for the Steam version!  To get cheevos, you'd have to shell out almost twice as much money and get it on PS3 or 360.  Ah well, no matter.  The goals are all pretty clear in LEGO games, so you don't need a list of achievements to figure out what's going on.

Do you love the DC Universe, particularly Batman and Superman?  Have you ever wished that you could enter into a living, breathing Gotham City just like the one in the comics.  If so, LEGO Batman 2 is the game for you.  This LEGO-ized version of the DC Universe is right at home among such Batman interpretations as the Burton films or the incredible Batman: The Animated Series.  The first truly open-world licensed LEGO video game from TT Games, LEGO Batman 2 features by far the best video game adaptation of Batman's home city.  While Rockskteady's Arkham games feature better gameplay and are better games overall, their adaptations of Gotham itself come nowhere near the version in LEGO Batman 2.\n\nLEGO BATMAN 2 gets a 9.5 OUT OF 10
